UK-wide day of action highlighting the urgent government help the sector needs during the covid- crisis.The live events industry across the UK will come together, at pm on Tuesday, August  to host a series of creative action to help save the live events and entertainment sector which is on the verge of collapsing without financial support from the government.Hundreds of venues are expected to turn their lights red in more than  cities across the UK to symbolise the industry going into Red Alert.In Wales, in excess of  venues and events businesses have signed up to turn red to stress the need for support.MORE STORIESWelsh Government aims to secure the future of Wales culture sectorWales Millennium Centre in Cardf Bay will close until at least January The show must go on - says owner of Waless smallest theatre, The Small Space, BarryA large collective from the industry made up of trade bodies, businesses, freelancers and venue staff, currently on furlough, will gather in groups of no more than in front of each venue to support the #WeMakeEvents #LightItInRed campaign.Wales-based events companies will light up their trucks as they lay empty on forecourts.Welsh venues confirmed to turning red are the Motorpoint Arena, Cardf Castle, Principality Stadium, City Hall, Wales Millennium Centre, New Theatre, Chapter, St Davidrsquos Hall, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, ICC Wales.Sarah Hemsley-Cole, director of SC Productions Ltd, an events production company based in Cardf said: ldquoCovid- has had a devastating effect on the live events and arts sector here in Wales, not only our theatres, but our touring shows, stadium shows, live music venues and outdoor arts have been decimated by the pandemic.ldquoThe ecosystem of our creative industry ndash skilled professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.ldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be continued.More title: around   jobs lost since lockdown started
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe ONS said that employment rates have continued to decline in the last month as another , jobs fell off payrolls across the country, pushing the number of employed to just under . million.However, the official unemployment rate is not rising, at .%. To be counted among the unemployed, workers need to be actively looking for a new job, which many have decided not to do yet, the ONS said.However, this does not mean that the people in question do not want a job, said Jonathan Athow, the ONSrsquos deputy national statistician for economic statistics. vw,vw,px, px"ldquoFigures from our main survey show there has been a rise in people without a job and not looking for one, though wanting to work, he said.ldquoIn addition, there are still a large number of people who say they are working no hours and getting zero pay.Between May and June employment dropped by the largest amount in a quarter since .The over-s, the self-employed and part-time workers were especially badly hit.Meanwhile, the number of hours worked by British employees has dropped to record lows.The ONS said that around . million people were estimated to be temporarily away from work in June this year, most of them on the Governmentrsquos furlough scheme.Around three million of these had been away for three months or more. vw,vw,px, px"And around , people in the UK were away from work because of the pandemic but getting no pay last month, the statisticians revealed.The number of people claiming benefits because they are unemployed or underemployed jumped to . million, a nearly % increase since March.The number of vacancies jumped % in May to July at , from a record low in April to June.Total nominal pay dropped .% on the year and regular nominal pay fell for the first time since records began in .Mr Athow added: ldquoThe labour market continues recent trends, with a fall in employment and signicantly reduced hours of work as many people are furloughed.ldquoThe falls in employment are greatest among the youngest and oldest workers, along with those in lower-skilled jobs.ldquoVacancies numbers began to recover in July, especially in small businesses and sectors such as hospitality, but demand for workers remains depressed.The worst of the job losses came in the beginning of the lockdown months. Many people were taken off payrolls as large parts of the economy ground to a halt in late March when Prime Minister Boris Johnson told everyone to only leave their homes to exercise or get food.Between March and June UK workers on company payrolls dropped by ,, according to ONS data released last month. Most of that was weighted towards the early days of lockdown.Experts are worried that the full extent of Britainrsquos jobs problems has been hidden by the Governmentrsquos furlough scheme, which promised to cover % of the salaries of staff who could not work because of lockdown.These furloughed workers are still considered to be employed, but many worry they will have no job to come back to when the scheme winds down.The furlough scheme ends in October, though the Government has promised a pound, per employee bonus to any company that brings back furloughed staff and keeps paying them until January.ldquoWhile the headline data continues to lag behind the reality on the ground, the decline in the number of employees on payrolls and hours worked is further evidence of the damage being done to the UK labour market by the coronavirus pandemic, said Suren Thiru, the head of economics at the British Chambers of Commerce.ldquoThe furlough scheme has been successful in preserving millions of jobs.ldquoHowever, with firms continuing to face a perfect storm of increased costs, reduced demand, and diminished cash reserves, unemployment is likely to surge as the Government support schemes wind down, unless action is taken.Chancellor Rishi Sunak, said: ldquoTodayrsquos labour market stats make it clear that our unprecedented support measures, including the furlough and title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Stolen car used in ram-raid attack on shopRestaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . title: campaign raise funds puppy kiros life saving operation
story: Attempted theft condemnedArmed men wearing face masks rob NI jewellery storeNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleCampaign to raise funds for puppy Kiro’s le-saving operationHe is just five months old and a typical exhuberant puppy but Kiro has been diagnosed with serious genetic condition which could mean a short le full of agony.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th August , : pm""An Alaskan Malamute, Kiro is a large puppy, full of energy and has become a vital part of the Goff household in Co Armagh.Christopher Goff, who lives with his family in Magheralin near Lurgan, explained how the family adopted Kiro in March from a woman in Belfast and he became a close part of their family.A full time carer for his mum Carmel, Christopher said the puppy had lted the family’s spirits, particularly since COVID- Lockdown as they had to shield due to his mother’s illness. Kiro.“Kiro has given us such respite. He is such a great puppy. He loves walking and is very happy. We couldn’t understand it when we heard clicking sounds on his hips,” said Christopher.He said when they visited the owner of the pups, they saw the puppy’s mother and were assured by the woman they had bought Kiro from that both were in good health. “They all looked to be in good health,” said Christopher.He explained that they took him to the vet for his first injections. “The vet stretched his hips and said everything was Ok,” said Christopher.Kiro“We became concerned as he was starting to ‘bunny hop’ when he was running andwe picked him up he would yelp,” he said.They took Kiro back to the same veterinary surgery for the second set of injections. Christopher said they were told that everything was good.But two weeks ago they noticed his hips were ‘clicking’.This time they went to a vets in Lurgan who said they could feel Kiro’s hips were ‘pretty bad’.“He has Canine Juvenile Hip Dysplasia and it is pretty bad,” said Christopher.The -year-old who isn’t working and is a full time carer for his mother and father, said they had taken out pet insurance but sadly it was not enough cover for this particular condition.He explained that it is a genetic condition and rectying it with a double hip replacement is going to cost around £k. Already they have managed to raise £,.“To give you an idea of how bad his case is, our vet explained that the worst case scenario would be a score of , where malamutes usually sit at around a .. Kiro’s hip scores are a .. This means he will require two hip replacements pretty much as soon as possible.“We understand it’s a dficult time to be asking for donations, and this is a last resort for us. “Our aim is to raise enough funds to get Kiro a double total hip replacement which would give him a new lease of le. “However,we aren’t able to raise enough funds for this, we will be using the money to give Kiro a double partial hip replacement which will help to signicantly reduce his pain. “Our vet also explained to us that by the time he is two years old, his condition will have worsened, therefore it is important we are able to give him the care he needs as soon as possible.”If you would like to help check out the Go Fund Me page here https:www.gofundme f kiros-hip-replacements utm_sourcecustomerutm_mediumcopy_linkutm_campaignp_cf+share-flow-fbclidIwARpDXrMFqgiBCOaISkLOKBos_YVaGicl_YbRFBEIpWJRHJOMYLrkA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: new store and  jobs pipeline
story: Stolen car used in ram-raid attack on shop‘Discouragement’ after man charged with indecent abuse of DUP’s Arlene Foster escapes with cautionNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsNew store and  jobs in pipelineA major new chain store is on its way to Lurgan and could bring  jobs to the town, a local councillor has said.By The NewsroomFriday, th August , : pmUpdated Friday, th August , : pm""The application, lodged by applicant Inaltus Ltd on behalf of Curly Properties Ltd is for a retail development with car parking, landscaping, access and associated site works developed atvacant lands north of Millennium Way, Lurgan.Originally submitted in  the planning proposal has been recommended for approval by Council’s planning officers and will,approved, see Home Bargains arrive in town.Speaking in support of the application, Councillor Joe Nelson said it would bring “signicant economic benefits… including some  new jobs” to Lurgan.“I believe the site location is ideal for this development as it provides adequate car parking in situ and is located on Millenium Way which is in fact the relief road for Lurgan Town Centre,” say the SDLP councillor.“Bringing this development to the town while keeping the town centre free from extra congestion is the ideal position.“I strongly support these proposals and trust that the material considerations, associated with the economic and other benefits of the scheme, will be considered in detail by the Council planners.”Upper Bann MLA Jonathan Buckley has expressed “strong support” for the application.“The proposals will see the delivery of a Home Bargains store for Lurgan along with signicant economic benefits including a multi-million pound investment into the local economy and the creation of some  new jobs,” said the DUP MLA“At a time when many people are losing their jobs and many businesses are having to close, proposal such as this, where successful major retailingbusinesses are willing to commit to Lurgan, the Council must give very serious consideration to these proposals.”However, an independentreview of the application by Tom Stokes Associated Planning expressed concerns that rather than support the town centre, the application,approved, is “more likely to create an alternative retail destination to the town centre”.The report said that with  per cent of the Lurgan town centre’s turnover allocated to just two stores, the remaining smaller conveniencestores in Lurgan could be “vulnerable to impact” by the approval of this application.The review also suggested that the proposal would be better suited to the former Tesco site in Castle Lane as it is “a key regeneration site in the town centre”.However, in response to this, the application’s agent, Inaltus Ltd, said: “If this site did not suit Tesco’s servicing requirements, there are no grounds for TSA to suggest it will suit Home Bargains.”In conclusion Inaltus Ltd’s response to TSA assessmentstates that whilst some aspects of the TSA Review can be agreed “other aspects are illogical and do not form a sound basis to refuse the proposal on”.It also notes that no objections have been lodged in over  months and called for the application to be brought before Council’s planning committee.The application is now set to appear before Wednesday’smeeting of the planning committee, with officer’s recommending that the application
